title: R46113
content: This report analyzes annual appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for FY2020, comparing enacted FY2019 appropriations, the Trump Administration's FY2020 budget request, and the enacted appropriations measures. It also provides additional informational resources on DHS appropriations and a list of CRS policy experts for consultation. The CRS Report R42638 provides information on homeland security appropriations, focusing on discretionary funding amounts and legislative action related to DHS appropriations. The reports do not cover mandatory funding issues or other legislation related to DHS programs. Specialized budgetary concepts are explained in the report's appendix. The curr_chunk discusses specialized budgetary concepts related to appropriations legislation, including budget authority, obligations, outlays, discretionary and mandatory spending, and adjustments to spending caps under the Budget Control Act. Additional resources for understanding the appropriations process are also mentioned. The federal government spending process involves budget authority enactment by Congress, fund obligation by agencies, and outlays for activities. The federal government spending process starts with budget authority enactment by Congress, followed by fund obligation by agencies, and outlays for activities. Budget authority determines the available funds for federal agencies and is established through appropriations acts or direct spending legislation. The Antideficiency Act prohibits agencies from obligating more funds than authorized by Congress. Budget authority enacted by Congress determines available funds for federal agencies. It may be indefinite or for one-year, multiyear, or no-year basis. Obligations are incurred when agencies employ personnel or enter into agreements. Budget authority enacted by Congress determines available funds for federal agencies, which may be indefinite or for one-year, multiyear, or no-year basis. Obligations are incurred when agencies employ personnel or enter into agreements, creating a legal requirement for the government to pay. Outlays represent the funds actually spent during the fiscal year, which may not always match the budget authority enacted. Budget authority can be obligated in one fiscal year but spent in a future fiscal year, especially with certain contracts. Budget authority allows federal agencies to incur obligations and authorize payments from the Treasury. Discretionary and mandatory spending make up gross budget authority, with discretionary spending appropriated yearly by Congress through appropriations acts. The Budget Enforcement Act of 1990 distinguishes between discretionary and mandatory spending. Discretionary spending is appropriated annually by Congress, while mandatory spending, also known as direct spending, is provided in laws other than appropriations acts. Some mandatory entitlement programs within DHS must be appropriated each year. Within DHS, Coast Guard retirement pay is an example of appropriated mandatory spending. Offsetting Collections are funds collected by the federal government as part of business-type transactions, not considered federal revenue but counted as negative outlays. DHS net discretionary budget authority is composed of discretionary spending minus any fee or fund collections that offset discretionary. The DHS net discretionary budget authority is made up of discretionary spending minus fee or fund collections that offset spending. Mandatory entitlement programs within the DHS budget include the Secret Service and Coast Guard retired pay accounts. The DHS budget includes mandatory entitlement programs like the Secret Service and Coast Guard retired pay accounts. Secret Service retirement pay is a permanent appropriation, while Coast Guard retirement pay is annually appropriated. Additionally, the budget contains offsetting Trust and Public Enterprise Funds that are not appropriated by Congress but are included in the President's budget for calculating gross budget authority. Enterprise Funds are not appropriated by Congress but are included in the President's budget to calculate gross budget authority. The maximum budget authority for annual appropriations, including DHS, is determined through a two-stage congressional budget process involving 302(a) and 302(b) allocations. Congress sets overall spending totals in the annual concurrent resolution on the budget, which are then allocated among congressional committees through 302(a) allocations. The 302(a) allocations are discretionary totals available to the Committees on Appropriations for annual appropriations bills. In the second stage, the appropriations committees allocate the 302(a) funds among subcommittees for each bill, known as 302(b) allocations. These allocations enforce budget discipline by ensuring they do not exceed the 302(a) discretionary allocation. The 302(b) allocations enforce budget discipline by ensuring they do not exceed the 302(a) discretionary allocation. The allocations may be adjusted during the year by the appropriations committee issuing a report delineating the revised suballocations as the appropriations bills progress toward final enactment.
